conclusion: The conductor that feels the magnetic force is the bar bridging the two rails; its length in the field is the rail spacing d.
Calculate the force on the conductive projectile: F = I d B = (10 A)(0.02 m)(1 T) = 0.20 N.
Calculate the acceleration of the projectile: a = F/m = 0.20 N / 0.020 kg = 10 m s⁻².
Calculate the exit velocity: v² = 2aL = 2(10 m s⁻²)(0.50 m) = 10 → v = √10 ≈ 3.16 m s⁻¹.
Calculate the kinetic energy at the muzzle: E_k = ½ m v² = ½(0.020 kg)(10 m² s⁻²) = 0.10 J.
Calculate the time the projectile is in the barrel: L = ½ a t² ⇒ t² = 2L/a = 1 ⇒ t = 1 s.
Calculate the average electrical-to-mechanical power over the shot: P_avg = E_k / t = 0.10 J / 1 s = 0.10 W.
Calculate the instantaneous mechanical power at the muzzle: P_exit = F v = (0.20 N)(3.16 m s⁻¹) ≈ 0.63 W.

Determine the final answer: When the projectile leaves the 0.5-m rails, its kinetic energy is 0.10 J, corresponding to an average launch power of about 0.10 W, while the instantaneous mechanical power at the muzzle is roughly 0.6 W.
